I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Jiangsu  Yancheng  Wetlands  Protection 
Project.1 

2. 
The project will support the implementation by the Jiangsu provincial government (JPG) 
of  wetland  protection  and  biodiversity  conservation  in  the  coastal  areas  of  Yancheng 
municipality  in  northern  Jiangsu.  The  proposal  for  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  financing 
includes five project outputs: (i) wetlands protection at the Yancheng Rare Birds National Nature 
Reserve  (YRBNNR),  (ii)  wetlands  protection  at  the  Dafeng  Milu  National  Nature  Reserve 
(DMNNR), (iii) coastal forest improvement at the Sheyang Forest Farm (SFF), (iv) coastal forest 
improvement  at  the  Dafeng  Forest  Farm  (DFF),  and  (v)  project  management  and  capacity 
development. Project preparatory technical assistance (TA) was provided.2  

A. 

Rationale 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

3. 
Importance  of  the  Yancheng  wetlands.  With  an  area  of  843,500  hectares  (ha)  of 
coastal  and  seashore  wetlands,  accounting  for  14.2%  of  the  national  total,  Jiangsu  Province 
ranks  third  in  this  regard  in  the  PRC.  A  significant  portion  of  these  wetlands  are  in  Yancheng 
municipality, where they cover 453,000 ha (30% of the municipality’s area) and stretch for 580 
kilometers (km) along the coast. The Yancheng coastal wetlands consist primarily of extensive 
intertidal  mudflats,  tidal  creeks  and  river  channels,  salt  marshes,  reed  beds,  and  marshy 
grasslands that provide desirable habitats for numerous species of flora and fauna of global and 
national importance. 

The  coastal  wetlands  in  Yancheng  include  two  national  nature  reserves:  the  YRBNNR 
4. 
and the DMNNR. The YRBNNR is very rich in biodiversity, containing 480 species of plants, 370 
of  birds,  281  of  fish,  48  of  mammals,  and  45  of  amphibians.  Twelve  of  its  animal  species  are 
included  on  the  country’s  first-ranked  list  for  priority  protection,  and  29  of  its  bird  species  are 
listed on the International Union of Conservation Nature’s Red List of Threatened Species. The 
YRBNNR  is  one  of  the  two  wintering  grounds  in  the  PRC  for  the  red-crowned  crane  (Grus 
japonensis), which is rated as endangered in the Red List of Threatened Species. About 60% of 
the  world’s  estimated  2,500  red-crowned  cranes  migrate  every  winter  to  the  YRBNNR.  The 
DMNNR is home to 25% of the world’s population of milu deer (Elaphurus davidianus), which is 
rated  as  ―extinct  in  the  wild‖  in  the  Red  List  of  Threatened  Species.  The  two  national  nature 
reserves  are  accredited  to  the  List  of Wetlands  of  International  Importance  under  the  Ramsar 
Convention,  recognizing  the  uniqueness  of  these  wetland  ecosystems  and  the  species 
biodiversity that they harbor. The DFF and the SFF, neighboring the DMNNR and the YRBNNR 
respectively, provide additional ecological protection to the two nature reserves and are part of 
the national coastal ecological protection forest network. 

The  Yancheng  wetlands  provide  important  ecosystem  services  to  local  communities. 
5. 
Local livelihoods are sustained through the gathering and culture of marine and estuarine plants 
and fish species. Wetland plants slow the flow of rivers, and the mudflats absorb wave energy

from  the  Yellow  Sea,  thereby  protecting  against  coastal  erosion,  tsunamis,  and  storm  surges. 
Wetlands  improve  water  quality  by  assimilating  some  of  Yancheng  municipality’s  rapidly 
worsening  pollution flowing from  households  and  industry. They regulate the  local  climate  and 
raise agricultural productivity. Finally, the two nature reserves, together with the two forest farms 
designated  as  provincial  forest  parks,  attract  hundreds  of  eco-tourists  each  year  from  around 
the  world,  generating  employment  and  income  for  local  communities.  The  ecological  services 
are  therefore  directly  linked  to  economic  development,  poverty  reduction,  and  livelihood 
enhancement for local communities. 

6. 
Government response to threats to Yancheng wetlands. Despite their local, national, 
and  global  significance,  Yancheng  coastal  wetlands  suffer  rapid  degradation,  wildlife  habitat 
loss  and  fragmentation,  and  loss  of  biodiversity.  The  main  threats  to  the  coastal  wetland 
ecosystems  and  biodiversity  are  (i)  land-use  changes  from  reclamation  for  agriculture, 
aquaculture, industry, and urban expansion; (ii) habitat degradation, especially in the core and 
buffer  zones;  (iii)  the  rapid  spread  of  invasive  species,  particularly  Spartina  alterniflora;  (iv) 
dehydration; (v) pollution from terrestrial sources; and (vi) poaching. Since the 1980s, over half 
of the wildlife habitat has vanished, while the area of fishponds and built-up land has expanded 
by  eight  times.  If  no  restoration  or  mitigation  is  undertaken  to  preserve  and  improve  wetland 
management, ecological degradation is expected to continue, risking the disappearance of the 
wetlands. The JPG is aware of the urgency of corrective action and has approved the DMNNR 
protection master plan, 2008–2030 and the YRBNNR protection master plan, 2008–2020. 

7. 
ADB’s loan projects in the PRC for environment and natural resource management have 
generally been well implemented. Lessons from ecosystem and biodiversity protection projects 
such  as  at  Baiyangdian  Lake  and  the  Sanjiang  plain  wetlands  and  for  Shaanxi  Qinling 
biodiversity protection were considered in policy dialogues with the government, the engineering 
designs  of  project  facilities,  and  capacity  development  programs.  Recent  ADB  reviews 3 on 
reviving  Tai  Lake,  Baiyangdian  Lake,  the  Sanjiang  plain  wetlands,  and  West  Lake  suggested 
that  ecosystem  protection,  biodiversity  conservation,  and  nature  reserve  management  in  the 
PRC are inadequately funded because society and the government fail to recognize the major 
externalities associated with ecosystem restoration. It is therefore important to build sustainable 
financing  mechanisms  into  project  design  and  conduct  policy  dialogue  to  mainstream  the 
financing  of  nature  reserves  into  regular  government  budgets.  These  lessons  have  been 
incorporated  into  project  design.  First,  strong  interaction  between  project  preparatory  TA 
consultants  and  ADB  missions  on  the  one  hand  and  local  design  institutes  on  the  other  have 
sound engineering design for the intervention that directly removes the most serious threats and 
responds to capacity development needs. Moreover, the project supports the development of a 
policy  framework  on  eco-compensation.4 Innovative  features  incorporated  in  project  design—
including rehydrating wetlands, controlling invasive species, converting fishponds into wetlands, 
and instituting sustainable financing mechanisms including the innovative use of public finance 
and  international  financial  institutions’  lending5—will  generate knowledge  products  that  can  be 
disseminated across the country and to other developing member countries. 

8. 
The  project  supports  the  PRC’s  sustainable  development  agenda  for  an  environment-
friendly, resource-efficient, and harmonious society, as outlined in the PRC’s Twelfth Five-Year

plans  and  the  forest  farms’  twelfth  five-year  plans,  introducing  an  integrated  approach  to

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

The  project  impact  will  be  improved  ecosystem  health  and  services  in  the  coastal 
9. 
wetlands of Yancheng. The outcome will be improved capacity to manage and protect wetland 
ecosystems  in  Yancheng  and  improved  livelihoods  for  local  people.  The  project  will  protect 
biodiversity,  identify  alternative  and  improved  livelihoods,  and  facilitate  local  residents’ 
employment and income generation.  

C. 

Outputs 

10. 

The project will produce five major outputs. 

11.  Wetlands  protection  at  the  Yancheng  Rare  Birds  National  Nature  Reserve. 
Interventions toward this output are (i) restoring 540 ha of degraded wetland in the experimental 
zone; (ii) rehydrating 1,630 ha of dehydrated wetland in the core zone; (iii) converting 1,435 ha 
of  fishponds  into  wetlands;  (iv)  piloting  the  control  of  invasive  species,  particularly  400  ha  of 
Spartina  alterniflora;  (v)  constructing  wetland  protection  infrastructure,  including  patrol  roads 
and  stations  and  waste-management  facilities;  (vi)  improving  wildlife  protection  with  the 
establishment of a rescue, breeding, and disease control center; (vii) establishing a wetland and 
biodiversity  research  laboratory  and monitoring  sites;  and  (viii)  establishing  a  public  education 
center and a community co-management center. 

12.  Wetlands  protection  at  the  Dafeng  Milu  National  Nature  Reserve.  Interventions 
toward this output are (i) creating 24.7 ha of watering holes for milu deer; (ii) establishing 45 ha 
of grazing and resting ground and 220 ha of fodder ground, closing 50 ha of grazing ground by 
rotation; (iii) controlling ticks on 426.4 ha, rehabilitating 24 km of wildlife fences, improving 18.5 
km  of  patrol  roads,  and establishing  a  patrol  station; (iv)  establishing  a milu deer  research  lab 
and habitat surveillance system; and (v) constructing the education center and the audio-video 
center. 

Coastal  forest  improvement  at  the  Sheyang  Forest  Farm.  Interventions toward  this 
13. 
output are (i) rehabilitating 185 ha of forest bird habitat; (ii) establishing 285.2 ha of nurseries for 
Chinese fir and evergreen trees, floral plants, and foliage seedlings; (iii) establishing 83.5 ha of 
agroforestry  demonstration;  (iv)  rehabilitating  51.4  km  of  drainage  canals;  (v)  establishing  a 
forest  fire  early  warning  and  response  system;  and  (vi)  establishing  an  integrated  pest 
management system. 

14. 
Coastal  forest  improvement  at  the  Dafeng  Forest  Farm.  Interventions  toward  this 
output are (i) improving 860 ha of coastal wetland protection forest; (ii) restoring or rehabilitating 
122.7 ha of coastal wetlands; (iii) improving 174 km of drainage canals; (iv) rehabilitating 20.9 
km of fire roads and establishing a fire prevention and response system; and (v) establishing an 
integrated pest management system.

 Project  management  and  capacity  development.  The  project  will  (i)  establish

The  borrower  will  be  the  Government  of  the  PRC.  The  government  will  make  the  loan 
proceeds  available  to  the  JPG,  which  will  grant  part  of  the  loan  proceeds  to  the  two  nature

20. 
A  grant  of  $2.5 million  from  the  Global  Environment  Facility  (GEF)  was included  in the 
March  2010  GEF  intersessional  work  program.  The  approved  GEF  Project  Identification  Form 
proposes  the  following  outputs  for  the  proposed  cofinancing  of  the  project:  (i)  wetland 
restoration  and  biodiversity  conservation,  (ii)  sustainable  natural  resource  management  and 
sustainable  livelihoods,  (iii)  ecological  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  (iv)  environmental 
governance. Subject to GEF approval, the ADB-administered cofinancing may be processed in 
accordance with ADB’s operational procedures. 

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

21. 
The project will be implemented over 5 years from July 2012 to June 2017. The JPG will 
be the executing agency, assuming oversight responsibilities and ensuring coordination among 
JPG  agencies,  such  as  the  environmental  protection,  finance,  forestry,  and  water  resource 
bureaus  and  the  development  and  reform  commission.  The  YMG  will  assist  the  JPG  in 
coordinating  and  supervising  project  implementation.  The  implementing  agencies  are  the 
Jiangsu Environmental Protection Department (JEPD) for wetlands protection at the YRBNNR, 
the Jiangsu Forestry Bureau for wetlands protection at the DMNNR, the YMG for coastal forest 
improvement at the SFF, and the DCG for coastal forest improvement at the DFF. The Jiangsu 
PMO  has  been  established  at  the  JEPD  to  be  responsible  for  planning,  coordinating,  and 
supervising  the  project.  A  municipal  PMO  has  been  established  in  the  YMG  to  perform  tasks 
delegated by the Jiangsu PMO. PMO has also been established at the city level to coordinate 
project  implementation  on  behalf  of  the  DCG.  Further,  PIUs  have  been  established  in  the 
YRBNNR,  DMNNR,  DFF  and  SFF  for  day-to-day  implementation.  The  capacity  of  the  PMOs 
and PIUs has been assessed and a capacity-strengthening plan included in consulting service 
requirements.  The  implementation  arrangements  are  summarized  in  Table  3  and  described  in 
detail in the PAM (footnote 7).

A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

22. 
Due  diligence  assessed  the  technical  feasibility  and  sustainability  of  the  project.  The 
technical  designs  of  the  project  and  its  outputs  have  been  aligned  with  sector  strategies  and 
priorities9 and  have  incorporated  international  and  national  best  practices.  The  implementation 
schedule  and  project  management  arrangements  have  been  assessed  as  being  appropriate. 
The  operation  of  project  facilities  will  be  undertaken  by  the  nature  reserves  and  forest  farms 
themselves,  which,  with  capacity  strengthening,  will  have  adequate  professional  operators. 
International consulting services will provide technical support to ensure that (i) ADB and PRC 
safeguard  policies  and  regulations  are  fully  complied  with;  and  (ii)  procurement  and  contract 
management, financial management, fund  withdrawal  and disbursement,  and reporting  accord 
with ADB and PRC requirements. Project design has a number of innovative features, including 

                                                
9 Sector Assessment: Agriculture and Natural Resources (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 wetland  rehydration  and  restoration,  the  conversion  of  fishponds  into  wetlands,  the  control  of 
invasive  species,  eco-compensation,  and  community  co-management,  which  can  generate 
knowledge products for wider dissemination.  

B. 

Economic and Financial 

23. 
Economic  analysis  indicates  that  the  project  is  economically  viable,  with  an  overall 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  14.87%  and  an  economic  net  present  value  of  CNY127.50 
million.  The  rates  of  return  for  individual  outputs  range  from  13.61%  for  coastal  forest 
improvement  at  the  SFF  to  21.70%  for  coastal  forest  improvement  at  the  DFF.  Sensitivity 
analysis shows that the project is generally robust to potential variations in costs and benefits. 
As the outputs are nonrevenue, financial analysis focuses on the fiscal impact of the project on 
governments.  The  annual  counterpart  financing  requirement  during  project  implementation  is, 
as  a  ratio  of  the  projected  government  annual  revenues,  ranges  from  0.02%  to  0.55%. 
Estimated annual loan repayment falls within the range of 0.00% and 0.11%. These low ratios 
indicate  acceptable  fiscal  risk. 10 Assessments  of  the  financial  management  and  institutional 
capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  and  PIUs  have  concluded  that  their 
financial  management  systems  satisfy  ADB  requirements,  though  gaps  have  been  identified. 
The existing financial management systems of PIUs in particular meet the general requirements 
of  the  government  in  terms  of  staffing,  accounting,  and  internal  control.  However,  PIUs  need 
technical support to strengthen their capacity to implement the project in compliance with ADB 
policies and operational and procedural requirements, which consultants will provide. 

C. 

Governance 

Financial  management  assessment  shows 

24. 
that,  with  capacity  strengthening  by 
consultants,  the  provincial,  municipal,  district,  city,  nature  reserve,  and  forest  farm  finance 
departments,  bureaus,  and  units  will  be  able  to  report  on  accounting  and  finances  to  satisfy 
project  needs.  The  offices  of  the  finance  inspector,  key  project  inspector,  and  discipline 
supervisor  in  these  organizations  will  perform  part  of  the  internal  auditor’s  function  in  internal 
control systems. Procurement capacity assessment indicated that (i)  the JPG has successfully 
implemented many projects financed by international development institutions, particularly ADB 
and  the World  Bank;  (ii)  the  DCG,  JPG,  YMG,  and  the  Tinghu  District  government  (TDG)  will 
establish arrangements for coordinating the various stages of procurement, including preparing 
bid  documents,  inviting  tenders,  evaluating  bids,  awarding  contracts,  supervising  construction, 
and monitoring contract performance monitoring; and (iii) PIUs will engage, through the Jiangsu 
PMO,  a  professional  procurement  agency  that  is  experienced  in  managing  procurement 
processes  financed  by  international  development  institutions,  and  technical  assistance  will  be 
provided  by  loan  implementation  consultants.  Procurement  capacity  assessment  undertaken 
during  project  preparation  confirmed  that  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  and  PIUs, 
acting  through  the  procurement  agency  and  with  the  assistance  of  ADB  and  the  project 
consultants,  are  capable  of  carrying  out  procurement  under  the  project,  including  advance 
contracting. However, as the DCG, TDG, YMG, and PIUs have not yet implemented any ADB-
financed projects and are unfamiliar with ADB policies, guidelines, and procedural requirements, 
ADB will assist and train them in project management. 

25. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the DCG, TDG, JPG, YMG, and PIUs. The relevant sections of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy 
will be included in all documents and contracts relating to the procurement of works and goods 

                                                
10  Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

7 

 

 8 

 

and  the  engagement  of  consultants.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 7). 

D. 

Poverty and Social Dimensions 

26. 
The  project  will  create  500  person-years  of  direct  employment  and  1,500  person-years 
of indirect employment during construction, with estimated total earnings of $16.1 million. It will 
generate  150  jobs  directly  and  400  indirectly  during  project  operation,  with  estimated  annual 
earnings of $4.3 million. It will trigger the creation of off-farm labor opportunities for surrounding 
communities  in  eco-tourism.  Training  for  off-farm  employment  will  be  provided  to  project 
beneficiaries,  especially  women  and  other  vulnerable  groups.  Women  will  benefit  from  about 
31%  of  the  jobs  during  construction  and  at  least  50%  of  them  during  operation.  Project 
implementation  will  respect  core  labor  standards,  and  implementing  agencies  and  contractors 
will respect national regulations. The influx of construction workers to the area demands raising 
worker and public awareness of HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. The project 
is  classified  as  ―effective  gender  mainstreaming‖  under  ADB’s  project  gender  classification 
system. A gender action plan to maximize gender benefits has been prepared to ensure that (i) 
women benefit from the project; (ii)  women participate in training, particularly on off-farm skills 
development, and that their particular requirements regarding trainings are taken into account; 
and (iii) women benefit from directly and indirectly generated jobs, especially if they are among 
the  households  affected  by  livelihood  changes. 11   A  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social 
strategy containing poverty and social impacts and mitigation measures has been developed.12  

E. 

Safeguards 

27. 
Environmental  assessment. The project is classified as category A for environment in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  A  consolidated  national 
environmental impact assessment (EIA) report for the overall project and an EIA report for each 
of the four proposed structural outputs have been prepared by certified EIA institutes. During the 
EIA,  adequate  consultations  were  conducted  with  stakeholders,  including  national  and  local 
government  agencies,  local  communities,  and  national  and  international  nongovernment 
organizations. The outcomes of the consultations have been integrated into project design. The 
domestic  EIA  reports  have  been  reviewed  by  a  panel  of  10  national  experts.  The  revised  EIA 
reports  have  been  approved  by  the  Ministry  of  Environmental  Protection.  A  draft  project  EIA 
report  in  English 13  was  prepared  by  the  JPG  with  assistance  from  project  preparatory  TA 
consultants and posted on the ADB website on 12 August 2011. An essential part of the project 
EIA  report,  the  environmental  management  plan  (EMP),  includes  impact  mitigation  measures, 
an  environmental  monitoring  program,  a  grievance  redress  mechanism,  and  a  public 
consultation plan. The JPG and the YMG will be jointly accountable for implementing the EMP 
and  compliance  with  it,  including  inspection,  monitoring,  mitigation,  reporting,  and  initiating 
corrective  actions.  The  DCG,  JPG,  TDG,  and  YMG  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the 
grievance  redress  mechanism.  The  institutional  capacity  of  the  DCG,  JPG,  TDG,  and  YMG  to 
implement  the  EMP  and  ensure  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  is 
considered adequate with institutional capacity strengthening by consults. 

28. 
The  project  is  expected  to  achieve  significant  environmental  benefits:  (i)  restoring  and 
protecting wetlands of international and national importance; (ii) conserving biodiversity of global 
significance  by  protecting  endangered  species;  (iii)  improving  the  national  coastal  ecological

12  Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
13  Environmental Impact Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 protection  forest  network;  (iv)  increasing  carbon  sequestration;  (v)  enhancing  the  resilience 
under climate change of local communities, particularly against the threat of tsunamis and storm 
surges;  and  (vi)  reducing  coastal  pollution.  Possible  adverse  environmental  impacts  and  risks 
during construction are noise, air, and water pollution; solid waste mismanagement; soil borrow 
and  spoil;  and  their  possible  effects  on  protected  species  and  their  habitats.  Major  potential 
impacts for the two nature reserves and the two forest farms during operation will be noise from 
water  pumps;  noise,  water,  and  solid  waste  pollution  from  the  operation  of  the  other  project 
facilities  (e.g.,  the  wetland  science  education  center,  research,  and  monitoring);  and  their 
possible  effects  on  the  protected  species  and  their  habitats.  All  impacts  are  expected  to  be 
prevented  or  acceptably  minimized  by  effectively  implementing  the  EMP  and  monitoring 
program.  Additional  specific  assurances  related  to  upstream  pollution  control  and  the  safe 
transfer of milu deer to the third core zone and/or other protected sites have been agreed with 
the JPG to ensure that project outcomes are sustained. 

29. 
Indigenous  peoples  and  involuntary  resettlement.  In  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement, the project is classified as category C for indigenous peoples and 
category  A  for  involuntary  resettlement.  The  population  in  the  project  area  is  ethnically 
homogenous mainstream Han. The nonrenewal of land use leases for 1,235 ha of land expiring 
before  the  commencement  of  the  project  will  see  493  people  in  156  households  economically 
displaced.  The  livelihoods  of  these  people  will  be  safeguarded  by  providing  new  land  leases, 
and  additional  measures  will  be  undertaken  as  necessary.  Detailed  mitigation  and  livelihood 
restoration  measures,  including  training  for  alternative  employment,  are  outlined  in  the 
resettlement  plan. 14  The  Jiangsu  PMO  and  the  local  PMOs  and  PIUs  are  responsible  for 
preparing,  reviewing,  financing,  implementing,  monitoring,  and  reporting  on  resettlement.  The 
Jiangsu PMO will engage an agency for external monitoring.  Loan implementation consultants 
will develop the capacity of offices responsible for implementing the resettlement plan and of the 
external  monitoring  agency.  A  grievance  redress  mechanism  has  been  established  to  provide 
affected people with sequential steps to follow in case of grievance. Affected people have been 
informed of the measures in the resettlement plan and grievance steps through public meetings 
and other means to ensure that they are aware of their entitlements and legal rights.  

F.

conclusion, with mitigation measures, the risks will be reduced to an acceptable level.

ASSURANCES  

31. 
The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project will conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

32. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions  of  Article  35.1  of  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  I  recommend  that  the  Board 
approve  the  loan  of  $36,900,000  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  the  Jiangsu  Yancheng

facility;  for  a term  of  25  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years;  and  such  other  terms  and

agreements presented to the Board.
